bibl.title: Letter from Wade H. Frost to Henry Rose Carter, February 17, 1922

div1.p: Frost asks Carter to give lectures on malaria and yellow fever at Johns Hopkins School of Public Health.

div1.head: Letter from Wade H. Frost to Henry Rose Carter, February 17, 1922
div1.opener:
Miscel
Lectures
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
310-312 WEST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, MD. February 17, 1922.
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
Assistant Surgeon General Henry R. Carter,
U.S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I have in my class in epidemiology here
a number of students from the Southern States and from
South and Central America, who are especially interested
in epidemiology and control of malaria and yellow fever.
As neither Dr. Freeman nor I has had any considerable
experience with these diseases, neither of us is pre-
pared to give more than an academic discussion of them.

Is it too great an imposition to ask if
you would be willing to come over to Baltimore and
give two or three lectures on these subjects, preferably
two lectures on malaria and one on yellow fever, if you
feel willing to undertake as many as three, otherwise
two lectures on malaria? I am sorry to impose on you
to the extent of making this request, but I have a strong
conviction that lectures are not really instructive
unless based on wide personal experience, and I do not
know of anyone else who is qualified to give a discus-
sion at all comparable to yours.

The hours available for lectures are Tues-
days from 12 to 1 or from 11:30 to 1, and either Tuesdays
or Thursdays or Fridays from 2:30 or 3 to 4, during the remainder
of this trimester, that is, until March 16th; and within
these limitations dates could readily be arranged to suit
your convenience.

I am sorry that I am able to offer for these
lectures only the very modest honorarium of $50; enough
to defray expenses, but certainly not enough to make the
lectures worth while from the standpoint of compensation,
so that I am obliged to base my request wholly on your
Dr. Carter
-2-
2-17-22
good-will and the school's necessity.

The class comprises about 30 students, practically
all of them graduates in medicine and for the most part
fairly well acquainted with malaria from the laboratory
standpoint.

With best regards to yourself and your family,
and hoping that you may be able to do us this very great
favor without inconvenience to yourself, I am,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, W. H. Frost.
Surgeon, U.S. Public Health Service,
Professor of Epidemiology WHF:G
